Kessler wearing a mask, glasses, a red tie and a dark suit." class="css-rq4mmj" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/01/13/multimedia/13DC-KESSLER-bgkh/13DC-KESSLER-bgkh-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/01/13/multimedia/13DC-KESSLER-bgkh/13DC-KESSLER-bgkh-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/01/13/multimedia/13DC-KESSLER-bgkh/13DC-KESSLER-bgkh-jumbo.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/01/13/multimedia/13DC-KESSLER-bgkh/13DC-KESSLER-bgkh-superJumbo.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 60vw, 100vw" decoding="async" width="600" height="400"/></picture></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-ImageCaption" class="css-ktho12 e3rygrp0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Dr. David A. Kessler’s departure comes as the Biden administration is working to shift Covid-19 vaccination from a government-run effort to one that will be handled by the private sector.</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Amr Alfiky for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div><div class="css-103l8m3"><div class="css-1u5onbp epjyd6m1"><div class="css-165eim7 ey68jwv0" aria-hidden="true"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/sheryl-gay-stolberg" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Sheryl Gay Stolberg" title="Sheryl Gay Stolberg" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/11/26/multimedia/author-sheryl-gay-stolberg/author-sheryl-gay-stolberg-thumbLarge.png" class="css-dc6zx6 ey68jwv2"/></a></div><div class="css-233int epjyd6m0"><p class="css-4anu6l e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemProp="name"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/sheryl-gay-stolberg" class="css-n8ff4n e1jsehar0">Sheryl Gay Stolberg</a></span></p></div></div></div><div data-testid="reading-time-module"><div class="css-3xqm5e"><time dateTime="2023-01-13T14:31:06-05:00" class="css-8blifj e16638kd2"><span class="css-1sbuyqj e16638kd3">Jan. 13, 2023</span></time></div></div></header><div id="NYT_ABOVE_MAIN_CONTENT_REGION" data-testid="region"></div><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — Dr. David A. Kessler, who for the past two years has been the behind-the-scenes force driving a vast federal effort to develop and distribute coronavirus vaccines and treatments, is leaving the Biden administration — another sign that the pandemic is no longer front and center for the White House.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">As chief science officer for the administration’s Covid-19 response, Dr. Kessler, 71, has operated largely unseen by the public. But his work — on issues like setting up mass vaccination sites, pushing for the development of antiviral medicines and distributing reformulated booster shots — has affected the lives of millions of Americans.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Six hundred sixty-five million vaccines, 13 million antivirals,” Dr. Kessler said in a brief interview on Friday, referring to the number of doses that Americans have taken since December 2020, shortly before President Biden took office. “We did what we set out to do.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Still, millions of Americans remain unvaccinated, and the public <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/15/us/politics/covid-booster-shots.html" title="">has been slow</a> to receive the new booster doses. When asked in an interview last summer if vaccine hesitancy frustrated him, Dr. Kessler talked instead about the mass vaccination sites, his efforts to distribute shots to pharmacies and nursing homes, and his work to make them available to children.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Our job was getting safe and effective vaccines to be accessible,” he said then, “and to make sure that everyone could have it, and that it was easy.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Dr. Kessler’s departure signals the end of Operation Warp Speed, which was started by the Trump administration to develop and distribute coronavirus vaccines. Although the Biden administration dropped the name, the mission of the program <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/15/health/covid-vaccine-kessler.html" title="">under Dr. Kessler</a> remained the same. Now the Biden administration is working to shift Covid vaccination from a government-run effort to one that will be handled by the private sector.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In his role, Dr. Kessler was responsible for negotiating with drug companies to make certain that vaccines were available to anyone who wanted one — at a price for the government that was far lower than what companies want to charge on the commercial market in the future.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">On Capitol Hill, some lawmakers are already gearing up for battles with the companies. Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent who has twice sought the Democratic nomination for president, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.sanders.senate.gov/wp-content/uploads/Moderna-Letter-01.09.20231.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">sent a letter</a> to the vaccine maker Moderna this week, warning its chief executive, “Now is not the time for unacceptable corporate greed.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">It seems unlikely that the Biden administration will replace Dr. Kessler. Officials say the Department of Health and Human Services has other doctors, scientists and public health officials with expertise who will work with the White House and private industry on vaccine research and development.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Dr. Kessler had hopes of building a more permanent infrastructure for vaccine development and manufacturing. In late 2021, the administration <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/11/17/us/covid-vaccines-supply.html" title="">announced a plan</a>, drafted by Dr. Kessler, to invest billions of dollars to expand vaccine manufacturing capacity by partnering with industry to prepare for future pandemics.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“This is about assuring expanded capacity against Covid variants and also preparing for the next pandemic,” Dr. Kessler said at the time. “The goal, in the case of a future pandemic, a future virus, is to have vaccine capability within six to nine months of identification of that pandemic pathogen, and to have enough vaccines for all Americans.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The plan was set aside, however, when Congress refused to give the administration any additional money to spend on vaccines. The billions the administration had hoped to spend to ramp up vaccine manufacturing capacity went instead to purchasing the updated booster shots now being distributed.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In Washington, Dr. Kessler may be best remembered for a far more public role, as commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration during the presidencies of George H.W. Bush and Bill Clinton.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Under Mr. Clinton, Dr. Kessler, who has a law degree from the University of Chicago as well as a medical degree from Harvard, took on the tobacco companies, and he later <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/books/01/03/25/reviews/010325.25kusnett.html" title="">wrote a book about it</a>. He also helped speed the development of AIDS drugs.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">When Mr. Biden was running for president at the height of the coronavirus pandemic, Dr. Kessler was one half of a two-person team — the other half was Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, now the surgeon general — who briefed the candidate almost daily on matters related to the pandemic.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">When Mr. Biden became president, Dr. Kessler took over Operation Warp Speed and ran it alongside Gen. Gustave F. Perna, who had worked under President Donald J. Trump and retired in 2021.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Dr. Murthy said on Friday that Dr. Kessler had been an “essential counselor on a wide range of strategic decisions” and called him “one of my absolute favorite people to work with in the administration.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Dr. Kessler said that he would wrap up his work in the administration next week and that he expected to take some time off before returning to teaching at the University of California, San Francisco.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Xavier Becerra, the secretary of health and human services, praised Dr. Kessler’s service in a statement.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“For decades, Dr. Kessler has worked tirelessly to address our nation’s most challenging public health issues,” Mr. Becerra said, “and his work during the Covid-19 pandemic has been no different.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div></section><div class="bottom-of-article"><div class="css-1i6tsou"><div class="css-h77nca eqi4ubu0"><div class="css-kzd6pg"><p><span class=css-97bxx6><a class="authorPageLinkClass overrideLinkStyles" href=https://www.nytimes.com/by/sheryl-gay-stolberg>Sheryl Gay Stolberg</a></span> is a Washington Correspondent covering health policy. In more than two decades at The Times, she has also covered the White House, Congress and national politics. Previously, at The Los Angeles Times, she shared in two Pulitzer Prizes won by that newspaper’s Metro staff.<span class=css-kzd6pg> <a class="authorPageLinkClass overrideLinkStyles" href=https://www.nytimes.com/by/sheryl-gay-stolberg>More about Sheryl Gay Stolberg</a></span></p></div></div></div><div class="css-1phdbhz e9ne27s0">See more on: <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/topic/person/david-a-kessler">David A. Kessler</a>, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/spotlight/joe-biden">President Joe Biden</a>, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/section/politics">U.S. Politics</a></div><div role="toolbar" aria-labelledby="styln-guide-title" class="css-1srdcl1"><hr class="css-1vbto68 e1mu4ftr0"/><h2 id="styln-guide-title" class="css-1lln88c">Inside the Biden Administration</h2><h3 class="css-10thtcb">Here’s the latest news and analysis from Washington.</h3><hr class="css-1jihs6t e1mu4ftr0"/><ul><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0"><strong>Terror Fears: </strong>The arrests of eight Tajik men who crossed into the United States at the southern border underscore the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/25/us/politics/terrorism-threat-fbi-tajik.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-biden-administration&variant=show&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc">deluge of terrorism threats</a> inundating national security agencies.</p></li><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0"><strong>Trans Surgery: </strong>Health officials in the Biden administration pressed an international group of medical experts to <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/25/health/transgender-minors-surgeries.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-biden-administration&variant=show&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc">remove age minimums for transgender surgery in minors</a> because of concerns over political fallout, documents show.</p></li><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0"><strong>Pardons for Veterans: </strong>President Biden pardoned some 2,000 American veterans who were <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/26/us/politics/biden-pardon-veterans-gay-sex.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-biden-administration&variant=show&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc">convicted of engaging in gay sex</a> under a military code that outlawed the behavior for more than 60 years.</p></li><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0"><strong>Student Loans: </strong>Two federal judges in Kansas and Missouri <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/24/business/biden-student-debt.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-biden-administration&variant=show&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc">temporarily blocked</a> pieces of the Biden administration’s new student loan repayment plan in rulings that will have <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/26/business/biden-student-loans-save-plan.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-biden-administration&variant=show&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc">implications for millions of federal borrowers</a>.</p></li><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0"><strong>Gun Violence: </strong>Dr. Vivek Murthy, the U.S. surgeon general, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/25/health/gun-violence-surgeon-general.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-biden-administration&variant=show&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc">declared gun violence in America a public health crisis</a>, recommending an array of preventive measures that he compared to past campaigns against smoking and traffic safety.</p></li></ul></section></div><div id="bottom-sheet-sensor"><div data-testid="lazy-loader"></div></div><div><div id="bottom-wrapper" class="css-sxwst7"><div id="bottom-slug" Kessler took over Operation Warp Speed when President Biden entered office, and his departure signals the end of the program."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},"timestampBlock":{"__typename":"TimestampBlock","align":"LEFT","showUpdatedTimestamp":null,"timestamp":"2023-01-13T19:31:06.000Z"}},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"WASHINGTON — Dr. David A. Kessler, who for the past two years has been the behind-the-scenes force driving a vast federal effort to develop and distribute coronavirus vaccines and treatments, is leaving the Biden administration — another sign that the pandemic is no longer front and center for the White House."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":0},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"As chief science officer for the administration’s Covid-19 response, Dr. Kessler, 71, has operated largely unseen by the public. But his work — on issues like setting up mass vaccination sites, pushing for the development of antiviral medicines and distributing reformulated booster shots — has affected the lives of millions of Americans."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":1},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“Six hundred sixty-five million vaccines, 13 million antivirals,” Dr. Kessler said in a brief interview on Friday, referring to the number of doses that Americans have taken since December 2020, shortly before President Biden took office. “We did what we set out to do.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":2},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Still, millions of Americans remain unvaccinated, and the public "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2022\u002F10\u002F15\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fcovid-booster-shots.html"}],"text":"has been slow"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" to receive the new booster doses. When asked in an interview last summer if vaccine hesitancy frustrated him, Dr. Kessler talked instead about the mass vaccination sites, his efforts to distribute shots to pharmacies and nursing homes, and his work to make them available to children."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":3},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“Our job was getting safe and effective vaccines to be accessible,” he said then, “and to make sure that everyone could have it, and that it was easy.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":4},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Dr. Kessler’s departure signals the end of Operation Warp Speed, which was started by the Trump administration to develop and distribute coronavirus vaccines. Although the Biden administration dropped the name, the mission of the program "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F01\u002F15\u002Fhealth\u002Fcovid-vaccine-kessler.html"}],"text":"under Dr. Kessler"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" remained the same. Now the Biden administration is working to shift Covid vaccination from a government-run effort to one that will be handled by the private sector."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":5},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"In his role, Dr. Kessler was responsible for negotiating with drug companies to make certain that vaccines were available to anyone who wanted one — at a price for the government that was far lower than what companies want to charge on the commercial market in the future."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":6},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"On Capitol Hill, some lawmakers are already gearing up for battles with the companies. Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent who has twice sought the Democratic nomination for president, "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.sanders.senate.gov\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002FModerna-Letter-01.09.20231.pdf"}],"text":"sent a letter"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" to the vaccine maker Moderna this week, warning its chief executive, “Now is not the time for unacceptable corporate greed.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":7},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"It seems unlikely that the Biden administration will replace Dr. Kessler. Officials say the Department of Health and Human Services has other doctors, scientists and public health officials with expertise who will work with the White House and private industry on vaccine research and development."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":8},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Dr. Kessler had hopes of building a more permanent infrastructure for vaccine development and manufacturing. In late 2021, the administration "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F11\u002F17\u002Fus\u002Fcovid-vaccines-supply.html"}],"text":"announced a plan"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":", drafted by Dr. Kessler, to invest billions of dollars to expand vaccine manufacturing capacity by partnering with industry to prepare for future pandemics."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":9},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“This is about assuring expanded capacity against Covid variants and also preparing for the next pandemic,” Dr. Kessler said at the time. “The goal, in the case of a future pandemic, a future virus, is to have vaccine capability within six to nine months of identification of that pandemic pathogen, and to have enough vaccines for all Americans.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":10},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The plan was set aside, however, when Congress refused to give the administration any additional money to spend on vaccines. The billions the administration had hoped to spend to ramp up vaccine manufacturing capacity went instead to purchasing the updated booster shots now being distributed."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":11},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"In Washington, Dr. Kessler may be best remembered for a far more public role, as commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration during the presidencies of George H.W. Bush and Bill Clinton."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":12},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Under Mr. Clinton, Dr. Kessler, who has a law degree from the University of Chicago as well as a medical degree from Harvard, took on the tobacco companies, and he later "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Farchive.nytimes.com\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Fbooks\u002F01\u002F03\u002F25\u002Freviews\u002F010325.25kusnett.html"}],"text":"wrote a book about it"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":". He also helped speed the development of AIDS drugs."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":13},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"When Mr. Biden was running for president at the height of the coronavirus pandemic, Dr. Kessler was one half of a two-person team — the other half was Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, now the surgeon general — who briefed the candidate almost daily on matters related to the pandemic."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":14},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"When Mr. Biden became president, Dr. Kessler took over Operation Warp Speed and ran it alongside Gen. Gustave F. Perna, who had worked under President Donald J. Trump and retired in 2021."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":15},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Dr. Murthy said on Friday that Dr. Kessler had been an “essential counselor on a wide range of strategic decisions” and called him “one of my absolute favorite people to work with in the administration.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":16},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Dr. Kessler said that he would wrap up his work in the administration next week and that he expected to take some time off before returning to teaching at the University of California, San Francisco."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":17},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Xavier Becerra, the secretary of health and human services, praised Dr. Kessler’s service in a statement."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":18},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“For decades, Dr. Kessler has worked tirelessly to address our nation’s most challenging public health issues,” Mr. Becerra said, “and his work during the Covid-19 pandemic has been no different.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"}]},"storyFormat":null,"storylines":[{"__typename":"AssociatedStoryline","ruleName":"styln-biden-administration","storyline":{"__typename":"Storyline","context":null,"displayName":"The oembed.title: Leader of Biden’s Covid Vaccine Effort Is Stepping Down (Published 2023)
oembed.summary: Dr. David A. Kessler took over Operation Warp Speed when President Biden entered office, and his departure signals the end of the program.
oembed.html: <iframe src="https://www.nytimes.com/svc/oembed/html/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2023%2F01%2F13%2Fus%2Fpolitics%2Fdavid-kessler-biden-covid.html" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true" title="Leader of Biden’s Covid Vaccine Effort Is Stepping Down" style="border:none;max-width:500px;min-width:300px;min-height:550px;display:block;width:100%;"></iframe>
oembed.thumbnail_credit: Amr Alfiky for The New York Times

readabilityObject.title: David Kessler, Leader of Biden’s Covid Vaccine Effort, Is Stepping Down
readabilityObject.content:
Advertisement

SKIP ADVERTISEMENT

Dr. David A. Kessler took over Operation Warp Speed when President Biden entered office, and his departure signals the end of the program.

WASHINGTON — Dr. David A. Kessler, who for the past two years has been the behind-the-scenes force driving a vast federal effort to develop and distribute coronavirus vaccines and treatments, is leaving the Biden administration — another sign that the pandemic is no longer front and center for the White House.

As chief science officer for the administration’s Covid-19 response, Dr. Kessler, 71, has operated largely unseen by the public. But his work — on issues like setting up mass vaccination sites, pushing for the development of antiviral medicines and distributing reformulated booster shots — has affected the lives of millions of Americans.

“Six hundred sixty-five million vaccines, 13 million antivirals,” Dr. Kessler said in a brief interview on Friday, referring to the number of doses that Americans have taken since December 2020, shortly before President Biden took office. “We did what we set out to do.”

Still, millions of Americans remain unvaccinated, and the public has been slow to receive the new booster doses. When asked in an interview last summer if vaccine hesitancy frustrated him, Dr. Kessler talked instead about the mass vaccination sites, his efforts to distribute shots to pharmacies and nursing homes, and his work to make them available to children.

“Our job was getting safe and effective vaccines to be accessible,” he said then, “and to make sure that everyone could have it, and that it was easy.”

Dr. Kessler’s departure signals the end of Operation Warp Speed, which was started by the Trump administration to develop and distribute coronavirus vaccines. Although the Biden administration dropped the name, the mission of the program under Dr. Kessler remained the same. Now the Biden administration is working to shift Covid vaccination from a government-run effort to one that will be handled by the private sector.

In his role, Dr. Kessler was responsible for negotiating with drug companies to make certain that vaccines were available to anyone who wanted one — at a price for the government that was far lower than what companies want to charge on the commercial market in the future.

On Capitol Hill, some lawmakers are already gearing up for battles with the companies. Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent who has twice sought the Democratic nomination for president, sent a letter to the vaccine maker Moderna this week, warning its chief executive, “Now is not the time for unacceptable corporate greed.”

It seems unlikely that the Biden administration will replace Dr. Kessler. Officials say the Department of Health and Human Services has other doctors, scientists and public health officials with expertise who will work with the White House and private industry on vaccine research and development.

Dr. Kessler had hopes of building a more permanent infrastructure for vaccine development and manufacturing. In late 2021, the administration announced a plan, drafted by Dr. Kessler, to invest billions of dollars to expand vaccine manufacturing capacity by partnering with industry to prepare for future pandemics.

“This is about assuring expanded capacity against Covid variants and also preparing for the next pandemic,” Dr. Kessler said at the time. “The goal, in the case of a future pandemic, a future virus, is to have vaccine capability within six to nine months of identification of that pandemic pathogen, and to have enough vaccines for all Americans.”

The plan was set aside, however, when Congress refused to give the administration any additional money to spend on vaccines. The billions the administration had hoped to spend to ramp up vaccine manufacturing capacity went instead to purchasing the updated booster shots now being distributed.

In Washington, Dr. Kessler may be best remembered for a far more public role, as commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration during the presidencies of George H.W. Bush and Bill Clinton.

Under Mr. Clinton, Dr. Kessler, who has a law degree from the University of Chicago as well as a medical degree from Harvard, took on the tobacco companies, and he later wrote a book about it. He also helped speed the development of AIDS drugs.

When Mr. Biden was running for president at the height of the coronavirus pandemic, Dr. Kessler was one half of a two-person team — the other half was Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, now the surgeon general — who briefed the candidate almost daily on matters related to the pandemic.

When Mr. Biden became president, Dr. Kessler took over Operation Warp Speed and ran it alongside Gen. Gustave F. Perna, who had worked under President Donald J. Trump and retired in 2021.

Dr. Murthy said on Friday that Dr. Kessler had been an “essential counselor on a wide range of strategic decisions” and called him “one of my absolute favorite people to work with in the administration.”

Dr. Kessler said that he would wrap up his work in the administration next week and that he expected to take some time off before returning to teaching at the University of California, San Francisco.

Xavier Becerra, the secretary of health and human services, praised Dr. Kessler’s service in a statement.

“For decades, Dr. Kessler has worked tirelessly to address our nation’s most challenging public health issues,” Mr. Becerra said, “and his work during the Covid-19 pandemic has been no different.”

Sheryl Gay Stolberg is a Washington Correspondent covering health policy. In more than two decades at The Times, she has also covered the White House, Congress and national politics. Previously, at The Los Angeles Times, she shared in two Pulitzer Prizes won by that newspaper’s Metro staff. More about Sheryl Gay Stolberg

Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent who has twice sought the Democratic nomination for president, sent a letter to the vaccine maker Moderna this week, warning its chief executive, “Now is not the time for unacceptable corporate greed.”It seems unlikely that the Biden administration will replace Dr. Kessler. Officials say the Department of Health and Human Services has other doctors, scientists and public health officials with expertise who will work with the White House and private industry on vaccine research and development.Dr. Kessler had hopes of building a more permanent infrastructure for vaccine development and manufacturing. In late 2021, the administration announced a plan, drafted by Dr. Kessler, to invest billions of dollars to expand vaccine manufacturing capacity by partnering with industry to prepare for future pandemics.“This is about assuring expanded capacity against Covid variants and also preparing for the next pandemic,” Dr. Kessler said at the time. “The goal, in the case of a future pandemic, a future virus, is to have vaccine capability within six to nine months of identification of that pandemic pathogen, and to have enough vaccines for all Americans.”The plan was set aside, however, when Congress refused to give the administration any additional money to spend on vaccines. The billions the administration had hoped to spend to ramp up vaccine manufacturing capacity went instead to purchasing the updated booster shots now being distributed.In Washington, Dr. Kessler may be best remembered for a far more public role, as commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration during the presidencies of George H.W. Bush and Bill Clinton.Under Mr. Clinton, Dr. Kessler, who has a law degree from the University of Chicago as well as a medical degree from Harvard, took on the tobacco companies, and he later wrote a book about it. He also helped speed the development of AIDS drugs.When Mr. Biden was running for president at the height of the coronavirus pandemic, Dr. Kessler was one half of a two-person team — the other half was Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, now the surgeon general — who briefed the candidate almost daily on matters related to the pandemic.When Mr. Biden became president, Dr. Kessler took over Operation Warp Speed and ran it alongside Gen. Gustave F. Perna, who had worked under President Donald J. Trump and retired in 2021.Dr. Murthy said on Friday that Dr. Kessler had been an “essential counselor on a wide range of strategic decisions” and called him “one of my absolute favorite people to work with in the administration.”Dr. Kessler said that he would wrap up his work in the administration next week and that he expected to take some time off before returning to teaching at the University of California, San Francisco.Xavier Becerra, the secretary of health and human services, praised Dr. Kessler’s service in a statement.“For decades, Dr. Kessler has worked tirelessly to address our nation’s most challenging public health issues,” Mr. Becerra said, “and his work during the Covid-19 pandemic has been no different.”Sheryl Gay Stolberg is a Washington Correspondent covering health policy. In more than two decades at The Times, she has also covered the White House, Congress and national politics. Previously, at The Los Angeles Times, she shared in two Pulitzer Prizes won by that newspaper’s Metro staff. More about Sheryl Gay StolbergAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENT
